Posts.Content: How do people deal with the restless sleep and waking in a panic at 3am? Does the hospital or GP prescribe tranx?
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: I’m in Oxford. I think there’s a place called Maggie’s next to the hospital and perhaps they do counselling. I can find out on Tuesday. It will certainly save the sanity of my poor husband! Thank you. So much. Xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for this. It really helps.  The next step for me is to see a surgeon next week. I also have private health insurance through work so apparently I can use this to get another opinion or be operated privately etc. I really don’t know what to do about that. The NHS has been brilliant so far. Guess I’ll wait to see what the surgeon says. I’m sure everyone goes through the same thoughts. I just keep thinking ‘what if it’s spread’ doom doom and then ‘oh it’ll be fine I’m 59 I only need another 10 years’ and then starting to cry. I need to focus on getting better and calm down! I’m glad your wife is well again.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you Ruby. I will definitely go to Maggies. It’s very good to hear about someone else’s experience. I see you were diagnosed after a screening like me. It’s such a shock isn’t it? And I’m sorry you lost your mum. But I guess we should be grateful we are screened regularly because otherwise we would have no idea if there is no visible indication. I just never thought I’d get bc. Everyone in my family gets heart disease and breathing stuff and I just assumed I was low risk for this - but I’ve learned so much in the last 3 days! I’m going to try to be as fit and strong as I can be for the treatment - even if it makes no difference it might make me feel more in control.  That’s what messes with your head - the feeling of being out of control and in a state of uncertainty. But it happens to so many women.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you all of you. My husband has been so great. He came in and just let me weep and spill out all the details again - and then we took the dog for a long walk along the river and through fields of waist high wild flowers, and then he took me for a pint and a plate of chips at the pub. It’s hard to be sad in a pub garden in the sunshine. And he (Paul) echoed all your wise words about taking it as it comes. He just said “it is what it is. You just have to accept that and deal with it as things occur. It will be fine you have to believe that.” When I’m with him I feel positive, but as soon as I’m on my own all the fears come back.  If I could just know that it’s small and hasn’t spread I think I could cope.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: The googling thing is the worst. Especially at 3 am! Thank God for this site and Macmillan. Xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks to you all. How do people cope with work? Does it turn out to be a comfort to have something else to focus on, or do you have to take a lot of time off? My work is academic and office-based so not heavy and physical. I think my employer will be sympathetic.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for adding to this thread people. It is the thing that is mainly helping me at the moment. I am so grateful that there is this source of information and support. I phoned my breast nurse today to see if they had any more info (because I didn’t ask anything when I was diagnosed) but it was an answer phone and no one Has phoned me back. Is that normal? Does it take a day or so? Maggie Mee - thank you for your epic post and for sharing your experience with me.  I hate the fact that so many of us (or any of us) have to go through this but not feeling alone is a real positive. Frilly xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: This is a very comforting post Dizzy. Thank you. I feel very touched by all the advice and wise words and I can honestly say that without this forum I’d be climbing the walls. You are the loveliest people. My mother in law had bc 30 years ago and she did without any support. It must have been so difficult. My husband is being very good too - he just says ‘think how fortunate you are: you were routinely scanned and they found it and they’re going to deal with it and you live in a prosperous western country with lots of resources and it’s all going to be fine’. And then he tells me to stop crying over the dog.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Got diagnosis yesterday afternoon. Thought I was ok but I feel really awful now. There was no lump and it was picked up on scan. First they said it was probably benign then they did biopsy and it’s a 2cm ductal cancer. Is this small? Is it really easily treatable? Sorry for the questions but because they had told me it was benign initially I just don’t know what to believe now. Just panicking I guess. Really grateful for any advice.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you to everyone who has replied. It’s anazing to see how lovely people are and it feels like all of you are the only ones who can help as you are all going through the same thing. I know it’s early days - less than 24 hours since I was told - but I’m finding it very hard to control my feelings (although I couldn’t really tell you what I’m feeling!). My husband is driving back this morning (he’s been working away all week) and I was determined to be upbeat and strong for him but I keep dissolving into tears. He lost his mum to bc 30 years ago and then his aunt and now two of his cousins have it. Maybe the news is just too raw and I’ll calm down in a day or two. Thank you so much for the advice.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you. These messages really help. I thought I would be stronger today but I’m already in tears. We are supposed to go to my friend’s pottery today. It’s in the countryside and I always love the drive there and then we have tea and cakes and take the dog for a walk in the fields. I’m just in pieces thinking about it. Why did I never appreciate before what a joy to do something like this without any worries? I know it’s illogical to think like this and I feel weak and silly. I’d allowed myself yesterday to feel bad and today I was going to crack on, but I just keep spontaneously crying. I think it’s the shock. Sleepless21 I really appreciate your account of your methods of coping. I’m going to try to do similarly. Did you get your counselling via the doctor’s? I have my surgeon appointment on Friday and then I can make some decisions. I didn’t really ask much at my diagnosis so I don’t know anything except that the cancer is in the ducts and it’s 2 cm and they left some sort of metal marker in the breast. The BCN said as I was leaving that they had checked the lymph nodes under my arm with the ultrasound and couldn’t see anything. I’m not afraid of treatment or surgery. I am afraid of all the waiting and not knowing what any of it really means and worrying it has already spread elsewhere. I guess that’s the same for everyone though. Ugh! What a way to spend a bank holiday weekend. All the best to you all.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: They didn’t say about the ER or PR positive thing. Does that mean it would be receptive to hormone therapy? If I phone the BCN on Tuesday would they know? It’s very helpful to be told it’s classed as early breast cancer. I don’t have a clue really and they didn’t tell me much - just asked me if I had any questions and if you have no knowledge of something how can you ask informed questions?
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks Julie. I have come to work today but am not much use as v distracted. However no one knows this as I have my own office to hide in! had a bad  night as I woke up at 4 am feeling I had cancer everywhere and couldn’t breathe (I’m asthmatic). But probably better here than at home. I told HR and they said I’ll be able to have as much time off as I need. I’m hoping that won’t be much!! Thanks for answering me. The waiting around is utterly unbearable.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: The bc nurse just phoned me. Apparently I have a grade 2 stage 1 ductal carcinoma. I forgot to ask if it was hormone receptive but she confirmed it was 2 cm.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hello all, Saw surgeon yesterday. I have more details now: it’s a 2cm er positive grade 2 cancer and no sign in lymph nodes on ultrasound.  I’m getting a lumpectomy and sentinel node testing then 5 weeks of radiotherapy and then 10 years of hormone tablets. I’m seeing the surgeon in her private clinic this morning to arrange surgery as have insurance through work. For someone with bc this is all good news so far right (I know can’t be 100% re nodes until after surgery)? Are the hormone tablets ok as in do they make you feel bad? Thanks. Jo x
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks ladies! I know I should be feeling better (even the surgeon told me that) but I’m still finding it hard to take it all in from time to time. Definitely better once there’s a plan of action as you have all said. My breast which was painless before, aches now but I guess that could just be worry and the aftermath of the biopsies. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hello, Your answer is very positive and encouraging (thank you) but I’m having a lot of problems dealing with this. I’m ok(ish) when I’m with people but if I’m alone it’s blind panic. I have no appetite and I can’t sleep. I know I’ve got to get tough but I just really don’t know how. Is 2cm really small and treatable? And they wouldn’t make a mistake about the size would they? Do you know what the probable course of treatment would be (the rough outline)? I’m sorry to ask you the same questions over again and I know compared to others I’m probably small fry. It’s so weird because I feel well and look normal. I just can’t get my head round it. My husband goes away for work again tomorrow for a few days and I’ve got to get sorted so I can be alone.
